item.title: The Art of Vibing: Reshaping My Website Using Antigravity and Gemini Flash
item.description:
Today marks a unique milestone in the evolution of my personal website. In a single session lasting less than an hour, I completely overhauled the aesthetics and layout of my core listing pages—Services, Projects, and Teaching—using Antigravity powered by Gemini Flash.

The process felt less like traditional “coding” and more like “vibing.” Instead of getting bogged down in the minutiae of CSS selectors or HTML nesting, I provided high-level aesthetic directions and semantic goals. Antigravity, with its deep understanding of my codebase and the lightning speed of Gemini Flash, translated those visions into precise, production-ready code.

Key Highlights of the Update:

  • Unified Card-Based Design: I transitioned the Services, Projects, and Teaching pages from standard lists to modern, high-density cards. Each card features a professional icon, subtle shadows, and a light blue background that feels both modern and professional.
  • Dynamic 2x2 Grid for Teaching: We pushed the limits of the layout by implementing a responsive 2x2 grid for the Teaching page. It balances course lists with active teaching photos, perfectly bottom-aligned for a crisp, organized look.
  • Aesthetic Consistency: One of the biggest challenges in web design is maintaining a consistent “weight” across pages. We harmonized font weights, bullet styles (using clean circular bullets), and spacing to ensure a seamless transition as visitors navigate the site.
  • Micro-Refinements: From italicizing nested project titles to ensuring semantic icon choices (like using a fa-sitemap for leadership), the level of detail achieved in such a short window was remarkable.

The “Vibing” Workflow

What was truly impressive was the iterative nature of the work. I could simply say, “This image overlaps with the text,” or “Make it more compact,” and Antigravity would instantly propose and apply the fix. It’s a “vibe-centric” way of building—where the AI handles the heavy lifting of implementation while I focus on the creative direction and user experience.

The result is a website that feels alive—more responsive, more professional, and more “me.”

Feel free to explore the updated Services, Projects, and Teaching pages to see the results of this AI-powered collaboration!

Most importantly, this blog itself is written by the Gemini Flash!

Special thanks to the Antigravity team at Google DeepMind for building such a powerful companion.

item.title: A New Chapter in My Career
item.description:
Zhejiang University

I am thrilled to announce that I have recently taken a new step in my academic career by accepting the prestigious ZJU 100 Talent Program award from Zhejiang University, where I will be serving as a “Young Professor” and doctoral supervisor. This is a huge honor and I feel extremely grateful for the opportunity to contribute to the academic community at Zhejiang University and continue my growth as a researcher.

Before this new position, I had the privilege of serving as an assistant professor at Aalborg University from 2020 and a postdoctoral research fellow from 2019 to 2020. My time at Aalborg University was an incredibly enriching experience and I am thankful for the opportunities I had there to work with and learn from some of the most talented and dedicated professionals in my field.

In particular, I would like to express my gratitude to my colleagues and supervisors, especially Prof. Christian S. Jensen and Prof. Hua Lu, who have provided me with invaluable guidance and support throughout my time at Aalborg University. Their wisdom, expertise, and mentorship have helped me become a more mature researcher and I will carry their lessons with me for the rest of my career.

Now, as I embark on this new chapter at Zhejiang University, I am filled with excitement and a sense of purpose. I am eager to work with my new colleagues and students, to continue my research, and to contribute to the growth and development of the university. Additionally, I am overjoyed to have the opportunity to return to my old lab and reunite with familiar faces. I believe that my experiences at Aalborg University and my passion for my field will serve me well in this new role, and I am eager to make the most of this incredible opportunity.

item.title: Spatial Data Quality in the Internet of Things
item.description:
MALOT Project

Within the framework of our MALOT project, we have published two papers in prestigious venues. Both papers are the outcomes of our literature review on spatial IoT data quality.

In November 2021, our long survey paper entitled Spatial Data Quality in the Internet of Things: Management, Exploitation, and Prospects has been accepted by ACM Computing Surveys (IF: 10.3). The abstract of this paper is as follows.

With the continued deployment of the Internet of Things (IoT), increasing volumes of devices are being deployed that emit massive spatially referenced data. Due in part to the dynamic, decentralized, and heterogeneous architecture of the IoT, the varying and often low quality of spatial IoT data (SID) presents challenges to applications built on top of this data. This survey aims to provide unique insight to practitioners who intend to develop IoT-enabled applications and to researchers who wish to conduct research that relates to data quality in the IoT setting. The survey offers an inventory analysis of major data quality dimensions in SID and covers significant data characteristics and associated quality considerations. The survey summarizes data quality related technologies from both task and technique perspectives. Organizing the technologies from the task perspective, it covers recent progress in SID quality management, encompassing location refinement, uncertainty elimination, outlier removal, fault correction, data integration, and data reduction; and it covers low-quality SID exploitation, encompassing querying, analysis, and decision-making techniques. Finally, the survey covers emerging trends and open issues concerning the quality of SID.

Later in February 2022, our proposal submitted to SIGMOD 2022 tutorial track has been accepted. The tutorial utilizes the structure of our survey paper and will be focusing on comparing the methodologies of representative works.

We hope to release the full texts of both papers soon. Thank you to my knowledgeable mentors and collaborators, Prof. Christian S. Jensen from AAU, Prof. Hua Lu from RUC, Prof. Muhammad Aamir Cheema from Monash U, and Prof. Bo Tang from SUSTECH.

item.title: New Survey Paper about COVID-19 and IoT
item.description:
MALOT Project

Our survey paper Impact of COVID-19 on Adoption of IoT in Different Sectors is now released at arXiv.

The abstract of this paper is as follows.

COVID-19 has disrupted normal life and has enforced a substantial change in the policies, priorities and activities of individuals, organisations and governments. These changes are proving to be a catalyst for technology and innovation. In this paper, we discuss the pandemic’s impact on the adoption of the Internet of Things (IoT) in various broad sectors namely healthcare, smart homes, smart buildings, smart cities, transportation and industrial IoT. Our analysis of this impact on IoT adoption is based on interviews with many industry experts, a thorough research literature review and a careful examination of reports from leading consulting firms. For each of these sectors, we also provide the details of recent initiatives taken in the wake of COVID-19. We also highlight challenges that need to be addressed and important research directions that will facilitate accelerated IoT adoption in these sectors.

This survey contains the most recent research papers about how IoT is incorporated into and affected by COVID-19 in vertical sectors such as healthcare, smart homes, smart buildings, smart cities, transportation, and industrial IoT.

item.title: Information of DBU Course (Fall 2020)
item.description:
Last Semester

Textbook: Head First SQL (Lynn Beighley)

Content:

  • Introduction (today) + basic SQL statements
  • SELECT, DELETE, UPDATE, NULL values
  • Be normal
  • ALTER, advanced UPDATE and SELECT
  • Multiple tables, creating table from data, Cartesion joins
  • Joins and subqueries
  • More joins and set operators
  • ER modeling
  • Constraints, views, transactions, and security
  • Database applications (1)
  • Database applications (2), review, and information about the exam

Arrangement (except the first):

  • Exercises for the first half
  • Lectures for the second half
  • Exercises/lectures the same venue!

Learning Goal:

  • Professional terminology of the subject of database
    • Proper understanding and use of relevant terms
  • Grasp of SQL statements
    • Use the right constructs and correct formulation (syntax) to solve practical problems.
    • CRUD: Create/Read/Update/Delete data.
  • Be able to know/do good database design
    • What, how and why?
  • Database applications
    • Application development and tuning
  • Database administration (a little)
    • How to share your data conveniently and safely?

Exam:

  • Open book, written exam
  • Question types
    • Multiple choices
    • Matching
    • SQL writing
    • ERD designing and table creating

item.title: ISQEA Project Open-sourced
item.description:
Indoor-LBS Project

As a part of Prof. Hua Lu’s DFF project DATA MANAGEMENT FOUNDATIONS FOR INDOOR LBS, the open-sourced project ISQEA (‘Experimental Analysis of Indoor Spatial Queries’) is released at Github https://github.com/indoorLBS/ISQEA. This project contains an in-depth benchmark with datasets, evaluation tasks, and performance metrics. The datasets consist of real and synthetic data characterized by distinctive indoor topology.

Along with this project, an experimental paper entitled ‘‘An Experimental Analysis of Indoor Spatial Queries: Modeling, Indexing, and Processing’’ has been submitted to IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering. This paper refers to an extensive experimental evaluation of five indoor space model/indexes that support four typical indoor spatial queries, namely range query (RQ), k nearest neighbor query (kNNQ), shortest path query (SPQ), and shortest distance query (SDQ). Our evaluation concerns the costs in model/index construction and query processing using a model/index.

Tiantian Liu is the main contributor of this project and I am an important participant. We will continue to maintain this project.

item.title: Assistant Professorship at AAU
item.description:
After a period of seeking faculty positions at universities, I decided to accept the Assistant Professor offer from Aalborg University.

To be honest, I have been working at AAU for a while and have developed a strong attachment to it. In addition, the offer from AAU provides a good integration with my MSCA fellowship such that I can still work on my fellowship while participating in the teaching activities as a faculty member.

During this period, I also participated in interviews with other institutions and met many excellent researchers. Although I did not choose to join them, I hope we will have cross in our future path, such as academic collaborations.

Working as an AP means that I will undertake more teaching tasks. As a green hand, I will strive to improve my lecturing skills and complete pedagogy training programs with passions.

I will probably start my professorship from July or August this year.
